name: Operation
overview:
This class allows you interact with Google Compute Engine.

First, install @google-cloud/compute with npm:

$ npm install --save @google-cloud/compute

If you are running your app on Google Compute Engine, you won't need to worry about supplying connection configuration options to @google-cloud/computeâ€” we figure that out for you.

However, if you're running your app elsewhere, you will need to provide project details to authenticate API requests.

Compute Engine

var gce = require('@google-cloud/compute')();

Elsewhere

var gce = require('@google-cloud/compute')({ projectId: 'grape-spaceship-123', keyFilename: '/path/to/keyfile.json' });

The full set of options which can be passed to @google-cloud/compute are outlined in our Authentication guide.

methods.name: Operation
methods.description:
An Operation object allows you to interact with a Google Compute Engine operation.

An operation can be a GlobalOperation, RegionOperation, or ZoneOperation.

examples.caption: Reference a region operation.
examples.code:
var region = gce.region('us-central1');
var operation = region.operation('operation-id');

examples.caption: Reference a zone operation.
examples.code:
var zone = gce.zone('us-central1-a');
var operation = zone.operation('operation-id');

examples.caption: All operations are event emitters. The status of each operation is polled continuously, starting only after you register a "complete" listener.
You can register a listener to monitor when the operation begins running.
Be sure to register an error handler as well to catch any issues which impeded the operation.
To force the Operation object to stop polling for updates, simply remove any "complete" listeners you've registered. The easiest way to do this is with removeAllListeners().
If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.
